reviews.text: a courtroom drama, musical hybrid that puts the Joker character and Joker the film itself on trial. Sadly, and surprisingly, this is conducted in quite safe fashion, the more inflammatory elements of Joker a distant memory

Todd Phillips delivers an inspired, thought provoking and challenging sequel that works so well until it completely falls apart in its final third with confounding character choices and plot resolutions and a final twist that insults fans of 2019's JOKER.

There’s little to zero point to any of it! Ask me what this sequel produces for the people who wanted more of the brilliant chaos from the original, and I’d have to think on it while trying to decipher if a shoulder shrug would suffice as an answer.

I found it enthralling, a bold genre mix ... [and a] subversion of expectations for a sequel, giving us not another gleeful retaliation against the slings and arrows of a mixed-up, muddled-up, shook-up world but a meditation between outer and inner selves
Joaquin Phoenix, an Academy Award winner for Arthur Fleck, delivers another powerful performance in Joker: Folie à Deux.

Seeking a minority opinion? Here’s one: Joker: Folie à Deux is superior to 2019's Joker in just about every way. There’s still plenty that’s wrong with it, but it’s no wonder incel supporters of the first film as well as fanboy critics hate it.
It starts out as a twisted, exhilarating love story between Joker and Lee, which is then forced to make room for a dull courtroom drama that mostly discusses the events of the first film.

A failed musical courtroom melodrama, whose bloated agenda betrayed Phoenix’s singular creation, a living entity of its own, haunting the popular mythos, which is possibly the worst thing storytellers can do.

When all is said and done, you may catch glimpses of the ambitious vision that Phillips had for this eagerly-awaited sequel, but it also becomes quite clear that he went a little overboard with his approach and tried to do far too much with it.
Phoenix doesn’t execute a single successful soft-shoe routine.
Joker: Folie a Deux is a masterpiece. Not a once-in-a-generation masterpiece but an ambitious and emotionally intelligent film that challenges everything it touches.
A tedious legal drama bolstered by dull musical numbers that lacks the audacity of its predecessor. [Full Review in Spanish]
Longer than it should be (it clocks in at 138 minutes), “Joker: Folie a Deux” is toilet paper on the shoe of a film that had a unique rhythm and an original point of view.
How dark and depressing is this movie? Let’s put it this way: If “Seven” had musical numbers, it might get to where “Joker: Folie à Deux” has set up shop.
Joaquin Phoenix and Lady Gaga give incredible performances as the Joker and Lee, but the overall story feels more like an Epilogue and not a standalone film.
It felt like it was trying to be too many things all at once and didn't accomplish them. Having said that, Phoenix is always good.
I was often bored, occasionally disgusted and only mildly entertained.
As well-made as the 2019 original but without any of its intelligence or mystery.
Folie a Deux is a 138-minute journey with a miserably empty payoff. To sing its praises would be a delusion.
The desire to break with the established order seems to me to be a bad joke made by awful people who hate the Joker. [Full review in Spanish]

Certain musical numbers are better than others, and the idea of why this is happening makes sense, but it begins to feel repetitive and unnecessary as we progress through this sequel that feels more like an extended epilogue.
Fans wanted the film to be one thing, and director Todd Phillips gave them another. That’s his creative right, and for me it worked beautifully.

Whatever specialness Joker can lay claim to—it doesn’t appeal to me, but I recognize it works for a lot of people—is gone in Folie à Deux. It feels like a money grab, like any number of superhero sequels cashing in on a hit.
While attempting to juggle multiple genres—a courtroom drama, a depressive musical, a twisted love story, and a social satire—it ultimately collapses under the weight of its own ambitions.
If you've been hanging out for the most depressing musical of all time, rejoice, that moment has arrived!
Joker: Folie a Deux has some visual flair, but that doesn’t make up for the plodding pacing over two hours and eighteen minutes, or its cursory examination of fame. It’s a folly that rings hollow.
The joke is on me because I really enjoyed it.

Joker Folie A Deux is more of an epilogue than a sequel.

Much of the film lives shadow of its predecessor, both in the subversive narrative and meta commentary.

The musicals, while fun, can shift tone abruptly. Just doesn't recapture the magic.
Why anyone thought this would work as a musical is absolutely baffling, especially when your male lead actor can’t carry a tune.
When everyone's a victim first, no one wins. When it's also the central premise of your movie, it tends to spiral into a self-pitying mess.
Bold and daring, Joker: Folie a Deux is also deluded. It's a ridiculous misfire that takes an awful long time to get nowhere and struggles to say anything coherent along the way.
A vague and incoherent bummer of a film that even the dedication and charisma of Lady Gaga and Joaquin Phoenix can't redeem.

The addition of Joker: Folie à Deux being a jukebox musical is a nice idea... but as a thematic touchstone to Arthur’s possible mental illness it feels like a thin thread that never unspools into anything emotionally resonant.
Set on tediously considering its predecessor, Joker: Folie à Deux offers nothing to the franchise.
The filmmakers haven't learned anything from their previous efforts when it comes to respectful portrayals of physical and mental disability.
I'm sensing that down the road, years after the outrage has died down, this imperfect, fascinating film will be rife for rediscovery. Now is not its time.
"A slog through two hours of vaguely comic-tented nihilism that manages to render both itself and its predecessor utterly pointless."
A $200M anti-joke with one grand statement: some films shouldn't have sequels. Ironic? Sure. But what could be more Joker than taking a feature-length piss? The joke is on us.

By swapping the Scorsese-inspired streets of ‘70s New York for a courtroom drama, Folie a Deux not only fails on its own terms, but manages to expose the hidden flaw at the center of Joker in the process: Arthur Fleck was never an interesting character.
It is not good. But it is art. And for that, it should be celebrated. Even while being wholeheartedly not recommended.
There must be a Venn diagram middle section of people who love both edgelord internet philosophy and visual nods to The Umbrellas of Cherbourg, but you need a microscope to find it.
Like Arthur Fleck, I fantasize about a world where this movie was never made .. and I dance and sing a lot in that world.
Without the fresh novelty of Phoenix’s portrayal of the Joker, spending time with his character becomes a tiresome, tedious experience.
...a perpetually subdued endeavor that falls right in line with its equally low-key predecessor...
Todd Phillips would rather set fire to his own franchise than let the wrong people take inspiration from it.
Phillips throws himself into the void with explicit but less substantial influences on the history of musical cinema.

I walked out of the theatre with a big smile while humming show tunes. I enjoyed this musical multiverse monstrosity, and Lady Gaga is simply dazzling. However, the target audience is not anyone who enjoyed its predecessor.

There is no doubt that Lady Gaga and Joaquin Phoenix put on a compelling dance, but the whole is not greater than the sum of the parts. You might love the acting, singing, and courtroom theatrics but all of that didn’t have me singing all the way home.
Joker is a story of grinding miserabilism, livened by a few scenes of joyful violence.
A colossal mess. It isn’t a “fascinating failure” but rather an infuriating one.
Dramatically inert, devoting 138 very deliberate minutes to revealing what was undeniable from the first film.

Muddled, messy, and unfocused, Folie à Deux could have been compelling and powerful...but that would have required a different director...and a lead with more interest this time around. Sidenote: Needed more Gaga.
There are moments when it works... but the overall story, doesn't feel much of a story.
“Joker: Folie à Deux” is bad but at least Phillips tried something new.
It is a very strange film... and I mean that as a compliment.
The film’s biggest hobbling is that its tonal and contextual (and textual) shifts don’t click.

The falloff in quality from "Joker," a genuinely searing innovation in comic-book movies, to this one is so steep that it’s comparable to the dropoff between “The Hangover” and “The Hangover Part II.”
It made me long for the Joker from my childhood. At least he was fun and had sneezing powder.

Phillips has made a bold and innovative film for which he should be roundly congratulated. The film is more modern thematically than so much of what the motion picture studios toss onto theater screens these days. It dares to be different.
Its approach wasn't a bad idea, the problem is that the musical numbers are poorly conceived and implemented as if they were making it up as they went along.

The singing didn't bother me, and one or two narrative twists left me mildly shocked. But nothing in this film manages to top what was done in the first instalment, instead making the events of that film feel sadly irrelevant. Full review in Spanish.
While I respect the movie's bold swings and found it to be visually mesmerizing, in the end it plays like an unsatisfying epilogue to the first film.
“Joker: Folie à Deux” is a film that takes bold creative risks. While it may not hit every mark, the solid performances and daring direction make it a compelling watch.
Joker: Folie à Deux promises to be a mad romp that celebrates one of DC Comics’ most notorious couples.
It’s impossible to repeat the shocking transformation we saw in the first film. But in Joker: Folie à Deux Phillips and his stars create something just as dark and fascinating.
Joker: Folie à Deux holds immense technical and artistic merit, but it fails to replicate the success and impact of the original.
A good movie could have been made out of the elements in Joker: Folie à Deux, including the musical numbers. Unfortunately, Todd Phillips was never the guy to direct it.
In the end works as a decent installment. [Full review in Spanish]
Phillips stays on the surface and lends them little physicality, little flair to match the songs...

Because both Fleck and his followers suffer from genuine social and economic injustices, the movie shows a willful determination from all parties (led by Gaga's firecracker Quinzel) to embrace Fleck's delusion a la folie à deux.
Folie a Deux functions as an overlong, pretentious coda – a slog that barely advances the narrative while regurgitating elements from the first film

Overlong but more finely tuned than the 2019 genre-bending drama, this sequel inventively swirls around musical sequences that use timeless standards to dig into the mentally unhinged fantasy lives of two central characters.
Where the original was a problematic but nonetheless well-made film, Joker: Folie à Deux could be a viable prescription for insomniacs.
Not a bad movie per se but its accumulation of ideas that never fully flesh out works against itself from beginning to end, delivering a colorful mess that feels like such a big misfire.
A frustratingly obtuse courtroom musical ... Yes, you read that right: courtroom musical. And it's insufferable.
Todd Phillips’ sequel is an empty, overly ambitious and superficial film full of mundane musical numbers that won’t ever freaking end.
While the intention is easy to admire, the execution remains disappointing. [Full review in Spanish]
FOLIE Á DEUX may mean this iteration of the Joker leaves cinemas with a whimper, but at least it finally had something to say with its dying breath.
Todd Phillips the rip-off king is at it again.
It’s a testament to Gaga’s weapons-grade charisma and star quality that despite all this, Lee’s scenes are electrifying and she lands every last line like a punch.
I respect the visuals, I respect the performances but... nah.

In many ways, Joker: Folie a Deux is a better film than its predecessor. It’s at least more willing to subvert expectations. Yet the weaknesses are unignorable and Phillips cannot help but shoot himself in the foot.

At a runtime of nearly two and half hours, it's likely audiences will get anxious. 
Visually Phillips succeeds in bold, striking theatrics. But sadly, any good in this movie is going to be overshadowed by the bad.

The mood, the look, and the stylings of this film mimic the first but feel at times like a pale imitation, continuing to tell a story that was potent and powerful enough without the need for further elaboration.
There are pacing issues, not all the musical numbers work, the film drags on unnecessarily, but Phillips achieves his goal. [Full review in Spanish]
The forward motion of the story is so minimal, and so broken up by long stretches of musical stasis, that the result barely feels like a movie.

This film explores the post-truth of its characters, offering a surreal and musical journey through the consciences of those who may be considered villains, but may also be deprived of familial, social, and institutional support. [Full review in Spanish]
Miserable it is...

A risk is that there are so many borrowings that Folie à Deux is more a collage than a film, but Phillips’ bizarre, admirable ambition scotches any chances of a Joker franchise by following through to a logical conclusion.
I found the film to be just as gritty and as moving as its predecessor, with huge performances from its two stars.
Joker: Folie á Deux is the rare movie that genuinely feels like it was made for nobody.
Like a clown strumming a sad song, this "Joker" is a major bummer.
An unnecessarily prolonged joke is worse than one told twice. Both things happen here. [Full review in Spanish]

There's a thin line between complex and confused and Joker: Folie à Deux never gets a handle on that line, leaving the impression of a film with something to say but is either not sure of what that something is or how, exactly, to say it.
Phoenix is a mighty fine actor, but this Joker feels more like an ego project for him and Phillips, rather than a film for fans.
... A daring leap into the abyss that disassociates itself from the first installment. [Full review in Spanish]
There isn’t an ounce of chemistry between our leads, and this shaky sequel spends most of its time dancing around in circles.

Joker: Folie à Deux has nothing interesting or relevant to say, seems to resent its existence, and wastes its performers. Phoenix doesn’t even look like he wants to be there. And frankly, we have to agree.
This is a remarkable film. Its originality and audacity, along with the extraordinary lead performance, are what, for this viewer, keeps movie-making alive.

Phillips uses  the Joker as the Trojan Horse to hide his concept because otherwise no studio would back an art house film about some sad sack guy who finds love and acceptance by committing brutal murders but loses himself in all the ensuing hype

The best way to face Joker: Folie A Deux is to go into it expecting something very, very different. By all means be entertained, be impressed but also be prepared for a finale that may not leave you completely fulfilled.
“Joker: Folie a Deux” is the most daring film to come out of a Hollywood studio this year.
What a waste.

My dour prediction wasn’t too far off the midway: Todd Phillips’ combined self-immolation and sustained “---- you” to audiences that plunked down their hard-earned is wholly in line with his lifetime of self-anointed punk attitude.

With nothing left to pillage from Scorsese and all his best ideas behind him, Phillips and his film are adrift and directionless. Although the meet-cute between Fleck and Quinzel is well-staged, the film has nowhere to go afterwards.
Great performance by Joaquin Phoenix, but the film is bogged down by unnecessary jarring musical numbers.
If you thought the gags in Joker were bad, Folie a Deux chokes, sputters, and flat lines to no applause.
Ultimately worth a look, but loaded with problems
Repetitive, shallow and clunky.
The jokes may still fall flat, but that doesn’t mean the punchline does not land.

This sequel reimagines the dynamic between Joker (Joaquin Phoenix) and Lady Gaga’s Harleen Quinzel, flipping the script on their relationship. Todd Phillips delivers another thought-provoking film, one that distances itself from traditional DC properties.

To dismiss the film for not meeting expectations is to miss its point entirely. It’s precisely in subverting these expectations that Joker 2 achieves its most profound impact, asking us to examine not just what we want from our art, but why we want it.
...registers most strongly as a tragic character study.
Undoing much of the goodwill from its predecessor, the sequel convolutes what could have been a unique character study into a bloated encore that goes out with a whimper.
Joker: Folie À Deux is a derivative, less sophisticated rehash of the previous film with unnecessary musicals and a dash of comic book spice that still leaves the film flavorless.
The ending of Joker: Folie à Deux ... is a total condemnation of the allure the people have towards Joker the icon over the broken human underneath the makeup.

Joker: Folie à Deux is a movie horrified by its predecessor, horrified by its success, its maddening cowardice to pick a lane, its public misinterpretation forged into perverse celebration of a lunatic with a bone to pick.
This movie is a disjointed mess and a waste of time. It's just tired, not particularly interesting, but it does look good from a production design standpoint.
Everything was teed up for "Joker: Folie a Deux" to be a massive success. It ends up being one of the most egregious misfires in recent movie memory.
Gaga and Phoenix are great, but the audacious musical character study 'Joker: Folie à Deux' doesn’t really go anywhere.
The best thing I can say about it is that it clearly does not take marketing, as it’s conventionally understood, into consideration.
An amazing idea on paper, however Phillips can’t help but continually call back to the stylized imagery of the first film, which somewhat undermines his thesis and ultimately rings hollow.
It's the Singin' in the Rain gag from Clockwork Orange stretched to two hours.

The mere existence of Joker: Folie à Deux is a complete betrayal of what came before, by someone who outwardly acknowledges (albeit in a pretty nasty manner) that a sequel to a solid one-off like the one he made is not a good idea.
There are parts where it seems like Joker: Folie à Deux is going to work. The musical numbers stop the movie in its tracks. There is not enough choreography or production to make them memorable.
Through it all, Phoenix uses cigarette smoke like an Olympic gymnast’s ribbon, buoyed along by a tide of confusion and cheers.
I’m taken by the audacity of it, that Todd Phillips is engaging with concerns from the first time out, and refusing to satisfy fan expectations. Too bad it's so dull.

Joker: Folie à Deux plays out as an underwhelming, unwanted epilogue to a film that did not need one. The film represents the traps of franchises, sequels, and IP. Sometimes, there is value in leaving well enough alone and quitting while you’re ahead.
By the end, it really feels like the joke is on the viewer, and as a viewer I didn’t appreciate that.
This is at times a thunderously dull film, listlessly limping its way through a leaden script that never quite commits to a reason for its existence.

It’s a bold and audacious concept for a sequel and your mileage may vary on how well it works, but I’ll take what is ultimately a slap in the face to reasonable expectations over yet another samey comic book adaptation.

It doesn't matter if he's really Arthur or the Joker. It doesn't matter if he wins his trial, it doesn't matter if society is broken. It doesn't matter if he gets the girl. It doesn't matter if he dies. And it doesn't matter if you see this movie.
There’s barely any plot progression until the cobbled-together third act, and none of the throwback tunes will have you singing along.
The creative swings hit more than they miss, making this a sequel that manages to stand on its own as a solid experience.
Our attention follows the protagonists, who are driven by the director with energy, verve, and emotional commitment, also through some splendid musical scenes. [Full review in Spanish]
Todd Phillips knows how to put the HA into being a hack.
If anything, Phillips is found guilty of his own count of murder by slaughtering the quality of his work.
A creative surprise with a lot of gumption, even if it doesn't achieve the excellence of its predecessor. [Full review in Spanish]

Lady Gaga shines and Joaquin Phoenix brings more of the same to Joker: Folie à Deux, a wholly unnecessary sequel with no new ideas and nothing to say. It doesn’t work as a movie or a musical. What a waste of $200 million.

The outstanding performances in this musical/psychological thriller can’t save the film from itself. The movie is overly aimless, self-indulgent, and miserable in the hopes that the audience will forget that it doesn’t seem to have a plot.

The musical performances are underpowered, lacking much movement, personality, or surprise. In fact, the film’s problems are so glaring that one can’t help but wonder about what happened behind the scenes.

With shortcomings of a hap hazard plot line, and awkward pacing in this too long film, Phillips curiously uses brutal violence with songs. Despite Phoenix, once again, unleashing his dynamic Joker, there are no heroes or villains, so the joke’s on us.
A self-indulgent, borderline pompous mess.

All these efforts to be unconventional and further push the boundaries of comic book movies produce a haphazard and repetitive picture with too many musical interludes and the most unexciting approach to two of comic’s most fascinating personalities.
Phoenix and Gaga give it their all, but whatever worked in the original simply doesn't here; this sequel is a long bummer of a songfest that makes us question why we're even watching this character.
As follies go Folie à Deux is dull and underwhelming.
The joke’s on us. Promising twice as much star power as the frantic 2020 Oscar competitor, Joker, the musical sequel Joker: Folie a Deux is half as entertaining and three times more irritating.
This could have been so much better.
There’s room for all these ideas in this expansive world, and this is a ride worth taking with Arthur Fleck and Lee Quinzel.
Why so serious, Phillips seems to be saying, in this follow-up. Relax, it’s all entertainment. The challenge, however, is that Joker: Folie à Deux is more ponderous rather than acting as a riposte.

This sequel is more than crazy this time around- it's absolutely bonkers!
What isn't bonkers is Joaquin Phoenix and inhabiting this character
Joker and Lady Gaga fans will surely find moments to enjoy, but they're likely to leave the theater feeling pranked.
As much as I hated the first one, this one works for me.
There are far too many moments in Folie À Deux where it feels like the filmmaker isn’t even trying.
Ultimately, it’s a wild experiment that mostly falls flat.

It's about loneliness, victimization, the class system, and, most importantly, how psychosis has been turned into another form of celebrity in American culture from our obsession with film, TV, and comic antiheroes to true crime to tribalism in politics.
Joker: Folie a Deux is a lifeless creative operation.
Turgid with misery, it’s basically the jukebox musical from hell.
Folie à Deux’s messaging doesn’t come off as artfully ambiguous, just so mixed that it could support any interpretation.
Joker 2: Folie à Deux is not a straight-and-narrow musical. It is, for better than worse, twisted. [Full review in Spanish]

...best seen as the punchline to Joker’s set-up, presenting us with the full story of this particular take on the character’s downfall while accurately summing up everything that... sucks about comic book movies, film culture, and audience expectations.
Fleck may not be able to live up to the expectation of others, but it's Phillips's Joker: Folie à Deux that sings the most disappointing tune.
Phillips’ premise is a half-baked romance, a yawning courtroom drama and an imbalanced musical.

“Folie à Deux”…. doesn’t play like a fully realized sequel. It’s more akin to an extended epilogue that follows the events from “Joker”. But the differences between the two films are significant and somewhat confounding.

Torch Song Triviality. Some of the musical numbers are interesting, but the sequel lacks a narrative theme or sense of cohesion. If the first Joker movie was lightning in a bottle, this one's a short-circuit.
But this is the overall issue with Folie a Deux. It takes good ideas and refuses to run with them, forever shying away from the big moment or the leap of faith.
It's boring, it's bizarre and it doesn't have enough Lady Gaga. It's not for comic book lovers, it's not for Little Monsters and it's not for fans of Joker. Honestly, it's just plain weird.
There are Todd Phillips movies where he proves himself a great filmmaker and others where he proves himself a great businessman. Joker was the first kind, Joker: Folie á Deux is the second kind.
Phoenix and Gaga try to save the day with daring performances but instead, they - along with the rest of the film - land face first into a pool of disappointment.
Joker: Folie à Deux can't escape the sense that it's just trying to get a rise out of its audience. Which is a shame, because it could have been a simple, sweet weirdo love story.

Joker: Folie à Deux is a failed experiment that squanders its promising concept and stellar cast on a lackluster and overly dour vision. Musicals may not be everyone’s cup of tea, but Joker: Folie à Deux managed to make the genre mind-numbingly boring.
Folie à Deux struggles desperately for energy and for emotion, but simply never finds it.
Once we get past the provocation of a musical, Joker: Folie à Deux is timid to a fault, a film that hides its lack of conviction and ideas in a conceit it half-heartedly explores

Joker: Folie à Deux is a product of wild, aimless ambition, the sort of mad swing that would be laudable if it weren’t so absolutely awful. It falls flat as a musical, as a courtroom drama, as a romance and as a character piece.
The decision to turn the sequel into a musical-slash-courtroom-drama is as perplexing as it sounds—and the results are so bad, they’re actually fascinating...
Rarely does a film plod along with such reckless abandon toward the idea that anyone is supposed to enjoy what they’re watching.
Folie A Deux is a jukebox musical that fails to hit the high notes of the original.

With Folie à Deux, Phillips gives fans a come-down that essentially punishes them for enjoying the volatile energy of the first film. It's more a corrective than a sequel, a Go Directly to Jail card in movie form.
Joker: Folie à Deux is a rather dull let down after the brilliance of its predecessor.

Folie à Deux is similarly far too involved in staging magnificent-looking sequences to chase its ambitions...the movie never gets there, leaving us with stunning visuals and an exploration of psychosis as limp as one of Arthur’s jokes.
Those looking for familiar versions of Harley Quinn or Joker will remain disappointed as these are some low IQ stand-ins that, even in their musical fantasies, still seem pretty drab and dull.
Phillips never pays off the promise of an extravagant song-and-dance spectacle, a full-blown Batman musical.
The sequel to one of the most resounding successes of the last 20 years shatters its own pedestal with an exercise in neurotic unhealthy glee. [Full Review in Spanish]
As badly misconceived a movie as I can remember seeing.

The blend of psychological drama with musical elements comes off as a failed experiment. It isn’t a terrible film, but it falls far short of the expectations set by its predecessor. Keeping expectations low for this unnecessary sequel might be wise.
It’s all immaculately staged and performed, but a bit of a drag. After well over two hours of this, it’s hard to shake the feeling that the joke may be on us.

The confusion is never dispelled. Portions of Joker: Folie a Deux are insanely incoherent. If that is meant to convey the convolutions inherent in the workings of two damaged minds, it does not quite work.

If Joker was a dark comedy, then Folie à Deux is its dreary, tragic twin with a frown stuck on its face. It’s a sour note for this franchise to end on but a great reminder that, eventually, all comedians bomb.

This edition of Joker may not entirely work, but it's daring, ambitious, and ungainly in crazy ways. Phillips' bold choices don't all pay off, but they beat the fan-serving rehash that might have been.
It’s as if Phillips and Silver’s Joker: Folie à Deux fell victim to their own delusions of grandeur
'Joker 2' is in its own way a kind of commercial suicide, leaving the feeling that Todd Phillips and Phoenix wanted to turn the page and say goodbye forever to Arthur Fleck (Full Review in Spanish)
[Joker: Folie à Deux is] a correcting of the record that exists more for its creator than its audience, an unnecessary skin-tag hanging off the original. And, most importantly, it's boring

Here’s a sequel we didn't need, trapping Phoenix and the glorious Gaga in a joyless musical retread that sucks the life out of the party. Says she to Joker during a fantasy scene, "Come on, baby, let's give the people what they want." I'm still waiting.

It casts Lady Gaga—one of the world’s biggest pop stars—but fails to provide her with the runway or screen time necessary to showcase her talents; she doesn’t even have her own solo, show-stopping number.
So, whether the movie is some middle finger by Phillips to the world or just a meaningless rambling, the joke really is on us.

Phoenix and Phillips go for broke again with a sequel that is equally bold and daring — not least in the way that it doubles down on the first film's rejection of Hollywood's usual comic-book playbook.

A boldly unconventional blockbuster that feels at once as disposable as any, yet has these tiny, almost irritating threads that when pulled upon reveal method to the madness. In this day and age, it seems, that’s entertainment.
“Joker: Folie à Deux” soars when it goes full-on musical, and bores with its thin story when it doesn’t.
Uncertainty is the best element of the film, which sees the performances kicking off at angles when you least expect them to.
Joker: Folie à Deux wants to critique a system that rightfully deserves to be gutted and inspected for its obsession with sensationalism but instead becomes the very thing it wants to reject.

Phoenix delivers another hauntingly powerful performance. His transformation from a helpless victim of circumstances to a confident individual representing himself in a murder trial is palpable, making his twisted journey even more compelling.
If you're in the mood for a bold, subversive, fantastic musical, watch Emilia Pérez.
Some viewers will want to clap along, and some will applaud because it's over.
Joker: Folie à Deux is surprisingly worse than its predecessor; it has plenty of songs but is completely out of tune.
For all of its attempts at bending genres and the out-of-the-box proposition, it nevertheless feels like an empty, lifeless and ultimately unnecessary follow-up to Joker.

Grating musical numbers, lackluster performances, and an incoherent plot make this baffling and bizarre entry into the Batman cinematic canon a tedious outing unable to embrace the weirdness of its own premise.
Another tour de force by Joaquin Phoenix who fixes us with his glittering eyes as the clown prince of Gotham alongside a somewhat muted Lady Gaga

If Folie à Deux were just a demented musical romance, it could’ve been something special in a small-scale, character-driven way. Alas, Phillips is somehow convinced that these Joker movies need to Say Something Important about the state of the world.
Maintaining the dark and rank feeling of its predecessor, the overall tenor of JOKER: FOLIE à DEUX is a daunting state of depression.

Gaga proves once again what an accomplished actor she truly is, although clearly Phoenix is the focal point of JOKER: FOLIE à DEUX. Still, with all its violent sequences, it’s difficult to heartily recommend this effort.

From the Looney Tunes-inspired opening to each musical number to its French titling, almost every component of Philips’ sequel feels superfluous and tangential—all incongruous parts of a film that inherently struggles to justify its existence.
This sequel is drafting off the first and comes up empty quickly. Despite all the flashy new additions (Lady Gaga, musical numbers, etc.), this is just one sad clown show.

When a movie from a skilled filmmaker misses as this film does, I perk up & start trying to figure out why. The film doesn’t do what audiences want it to do. Yes. But it can’t be that simple. There has to be a reason Todd Phillips went to work every day.
Folie à Deux achieves a feat that few sequels – even the worst ones – have accomplished: it makes the original film worse in retrospect. [Full review in Portuguese]
This sequel is neither a good musical nor a good legal procedural drama and Lady Gaga's talent as an actress and a singer are both wasted.
